p: In 1796, Edward Jenner, who had been variolated, discovered the vaccination principle when he used the cowpox virus live-vaccine (vaccinia virus) to induce cross-immunity and prevent human smallpox in a child. His strong merit was to initiate the campaign that turned vaccination against smallpox obligatory and universal, and to discover that cross-protection promoted by a heterologous, although related, organism was sufficient to guarantee efficacy and reduce the safety issues of the homologous live-vaccine ( 6).
